Skut,"2015-07-16T00:03:24.463Z","One of the best Lego choppers ever","

This is a magnificent set and a real highlight of the Arctic (or, for those of us in the Southern hemisphere, Antarctic) line.
column4: s best ever helicopters in the City theme.&nbsp

column1: The parts array is impressive, with Technic elements used to give structural rigidity to the helicopter'
column3: The overall look of the helicopter strongly resembles an Erickson/Sikorsky S-64 aircrane - perhaps a similar set can be included in the next round of Fire sets as a waterbomber?

column1: The dog sled team is a great part of the set and really adds to playability.
column2: The arctic dog element is a great addition to the Lego animals &quot
column4: and showcases how far brick printing technology has come.&nbsp

column1: The Polar-clad minifigs are well up to the standards of printing and quality we have come to expect from TLG.

column4: s winch mechanism is affixed only by a 2x2 plate which means it has a tendency to come loose when hoisting up the cargo pallet.&nbsp
column5: The cargo pallet also suffers from some structural weakness and two 1x4 plates or four 2x2 corner plates from your spares collection will be needed to reinforce it.&nbsp

column1: And of course, as a City set (apart from trains), it features the egregious white-paper stickers which are lucky to last 2 years before cracking, splintering or falling off.
column3: Given these stickers are intended to be applied to&nbsp
column4: elements that last decades, this is not good enough.&nbsp
column5: TLG must do better in this area (ie. clear film stickers or printed bricks in all sets)&nbsp
column6: or risk a customer class action for selling goods of unmerchantable quality.&nbsp

column3: great set for kids and AFOLS alike with stacks of play value and swooshability.&nbsp
